Description: 2K approach is more about timing than changing your swing. Shift your timing to be slightly later so you catch the ball deeper in the zone when taking a normal swing. You'll have more time to make better swing decisions and adjust to different pitches.
Equipment: Partner (defense / hitting), Batting Machine, Bat, Baseballs

Description:
Your hands control how you adjust to different locations.

Train muscle memory to get to contact,
short to the ball, long through it.

Should feel smooth and low effort —
just like your game swing.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
If you struggle with getting too far out front, lunging, or having poor timing, this drill helps you stay controlled and balanced during your swing. 

Staying stacked on your back leg allows you to put all of your force into the ball at contact.

Train your swing so you don't need to be perfect in order to have success. 


 athletic and controlled in your back leg.
Skills: Timing, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Staying steady on your back leg helps with your timing and direction to the middle of the field. 

If you're lunging forward or off balance, use this feel to recenter yourself and control your swing with your back leg.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
You're training your swing to be shorter and more direct to the ball. 

If you keep your hands close to your shoulder as you swing, you'll improve your bat speed, contact, and power. 

Feel like your back shoulder leads your swing, with your hands along for the ride.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Velocity, Contact

Description:
When you rotate, it's easy to spin off the ball or roll over. 

This feel helps you turn to contact while staying through the ball and keeping your upper and lower body connected.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Build muscle memory to fully load your back hip each time you swing. 

Your hips are among your most powerful muscles and will help you transfer all of your energy into the ball. 

Maintain tension in your back hip as you load and swing.

You lose power and consistency when you push your hands to the ball. 

This drill builds muscle memory to rotate through contact, using your core and hips to hit the ball rather than relying on your arm strength.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
You're swinging until your eyes tell you to stop. 

Being aggressive means controlling your weight, timing and launch position to be as athletic as possible.

Training yourself to stay in your legs and keep your head level as you swing will build power and more consistent contact. 

Make sure you aren't drifting your upper body forward and instead stay in between your legs as you rotate to the ball.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description: Own your load and be ready at the pitcher's release. On time for the pitcher's best fastball.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Your bottom hand determines the direction of your swing. 

Train yourself to stay through the ball to the middle of the field. 

Keep your front shoulder pointed toward the pitcher as long as you can.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Your bottom hand determines the direction of your swing. 

Train yourself to stay through the ball to the middle of the field. 

Keep your front shoulder pointed toward the pitcher as long as you can.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Consistent contact starts by being ready at release. 

Get to your launch position and make a tight turn to the ball.

The initial move you make to the baseball needs to be quick and impactful. 

Be ready at release, ready to unload on the ball.

As you square to bunt, point your bat to third base so that you preset your angle to the first base side. 

Adjust to the pitch using your legs, keeping your eyes behind the bat.

As you square to bunt, point your bat to first base so that you preset your angle to the third base side. 

Adjust to the pitch using your legs, keeping your eyes behind the bat.

Get the barrel in the zone as a result of your turn. 

Your hands should just be along for the ride.
Skills: Contact, Staying Back, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Drill Name: Choked Up Static Feet Front Toss
Description:
If you're casting, have a long swing, or are getting jammed, remember the feel from this drill. 

Choking up on the bat forces you to be direct to the ball with no wasted movement.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
If you're casting, have a long swing, or are getting jammed, remember the feel from this drill. 

Choking up on the bat forces you to be direct to the ball with no wasted movement.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
If you're popping up, have low bat speed, or can't pull the ball in the air, practice getting your barrel out in front of your hands. 

Build bat speed and hit against your front side without drifting.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
You need to stay through the ball while the rest of your body loads and rotates. 

Build muscle memory keeping your direction working to the middle of the field while using your hips to generate power.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
You need to stay through the ball while the rest of your body loads and rotates. 

Build muscle memory keeping your direction working to the middle of the field while using your hips to generate power.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Exaggerating your leg kick will help you get comfortable loading earlier and slower in games. 

If you feel rushed or late, remember the feeling from this drill where you stay under control during your stride.

You need to be short to the ball and long through it, on plane with the pitch as long as possible. 

Give yourself the most margin for error to hit the ball.

If you try to do too much, you'll lose power and make inconsistent contact. 

Stay within yourself and trust your swing.
Skills: Power, Staying Back, Timing, Swing Decisions

Description:
Your lower half needs to brake in order for your bat to speed up through the ball. 

Post up with your front leg and rotate through the middle of the field.

Train your body to move in sync and work together. 

Using your whole body allows you to hit for more power and adjust to different pitches in games. 

Your hands and front leg should move in opposite directions, building tension in your core that can be transferred into the ball.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Challenge yourself to adapt to pitches at different speeds and contact points. 

Take one swing starting from the back plate, then move up to the closer plate and take another swing.

Control your timing and know when to start your load in order to be on time.
Skills: Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Get into the zone by turning behind the ball. 

Stay short to the ball, catching it deep in the zone and extend after contact.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Contact

Description:
You need to control your weight using your back hip without drifting forward. 

This feel trains your back leg to control your load and stride—perfect if you struggle with lunging, drifting, or timing.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
When your front foot hits the ground, you should feel powerful and balanced. 

You need to be able to adjust to different speeds and locations from your launch position without having to load again before swinging.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Drill Name: Dry Rep Launch Position Sit Downs
Description:
You're training how to use your legs and be in a powerful position when your front foot hits the ground. 

If you're drifting forward, spinning off or not getting enough power remember this feel and apply it in games.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
You need to be able to rotate your hips and core without flying open with your shoulders. 

This feel helps you generate more power while staying through the ball, to the middle of the field.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
You should be able to swing at 40-50% effort and stay in control of your swing. 

Your best in-game swings will feel light and easy, with your adrenaline supplying the energy.

Rotating to the ball without drifting forward allows you to make better contact and increase your bat speed. 

This drill is a great feel for making a tight turn to the ball, helping you hit high velocity.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Train your body to swing hard without muscling up with your shoulders and arms. 

Your legs, hips, and core are your most powerful muscles, so use them to impact the ball.

Extension comes after you make contact, not before. 

Turn to the ball and extend through the baseball.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Contact

Description:
Starting with your leg in the air forces you to control your load and stride with your back hip. 

Sink into your hip as you move forward.

Controlling your swing from your back leg helps with your timing, power, and adjusting to different pitches.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
Staying grounded helps you adjust to different pitches and make consistent contact. 

Stay balanced and swing using your core to rotate to the ball.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Contact, Hitting Fastballs

Drill Name: Front Side Connection Ball Tee Drill
Description:
Build the muscle memory to keep your hands back and front side closed as you swing. 

You'll stay through the ball longer, and it'll be easier to adjust to different pitches in games.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Swinging hard doesn't mean muscling up with your shoulders and arms or forcing the ball to the pull side. 

Use your legs, core, and hips to rotate hard while keeping your hands working through the middle of the field.

Train your body to fully rotate through the baseball while staying balanced. 

Your swing should feel smooth and loose in games, and this drill helps your body build that feel.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
During BP, you should be able to direct the ball where you want it to go. 

Hitting a groundball doesn't mean changing your swing—simply catch the ball deeper in the zone as you take a normal swing.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
You need to be able to rotate your hips and core without flying open with your shoulders. 

This feel helps you generate more power while staying through the ball to the middle of the field.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Try this feel if you're pulling off the ball. 

Finishing with your hands high can help you stay long through the zone rather than cutting yourself off to the side.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Power, Contact

Drill Name: High Leg Kick to Launch Tee Drill
Description:
It's easy to rush before your entire body is in a good position to swing. 

You're taking control of when you decide to swing and making sure your entire body moves in sync.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Hitting the ball to the opposite field does not mean forcing it or changing your swing. 

Let the ball get deep in the zone and take a normal swing. 

If your bat path is where it should be, then you'll hit the ball to the opposite field after letting the pitch get deep.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Keep a tight turn and then extend through the ball in order to backspin inside pitches. 

Get behind the ball without rushing or cutting off your swing.

Keep your bat and shoulder connected in order to drive pitches lower in the zone. 

Your attack angle should work up and through the pitch.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Drill Name: Hitting Pitches Up in the Zone
Description:
Match your shoulder plane to the pitch. 

Don't try to do too much, turn to the ball and stay through the middle of the field.

You don't need to force or manipulate the ball to hit it the other way. 

Catch the ball deep in the zone using a tight turn through the zone.

You hit the ball to the opposite field by catching the ball deeper in the zone. 

Get on plane early and you'll hit it to all parts of the field.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back

Description:
Your swing during practice/BP should always be under control, smooth, and balanced. 

In games, your swing should have the same effort level—the competition and your adrenaline will naturally cause you to swing harder.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Drill Name: How to Load Your Back Hip
Description:
Screw your back heel into the ground as you load. 

Hold tension in your back hip until you attack the ball.

Let the back shoulder open up the swing and deliver the barrel. 

The front must stay closed as long as possible.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball

Description:
Push everything into the ground and stay athletic. 

Your head should stay still as you rotate to the ball.

Being ready at release allows you to get your best swing off and adjust to different speeds and locations. 

Control your weight using your back hip so you aren't lunging or getting stuck in your load.
Skills: Timing, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Your bottom hand determines the direction of your swing. 

Train yourself to stay through the ball to the middle of the field. 

Keep your front shoulder pointed toward the pitcher as long as you can.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Keep the bat close to your shoulder during the turn.

Front shoulder stays closed as long as possible.

Helps with:
• Compact swing
• Better control
• More power

Short to the ball, long through it 💪

Like always, stay athletic.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Starting with your leg in the air forces you to control your load and stride with your back hip. 

Sink into your hip as you move forward. 

Controlling your swing from your back leg helps with your timing, power, and adjusting to different pitches.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
Your load and rotation to the ball should be powerful and directed up the middle of the field. 

Train yourself to load and rotate explosively using your big muscles (hips, core, and legs) instead of your arms and shoulders.

Start slow and controlled, waiting on the pitch to enter the zone. 

Be ready to hit the pitcher's best fastball.
Skills: Timing, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Load and get to your launch position, holding your weight in your back hip. 

As you rotate the waterbag through the zone, keep your legs and core stable. 

You're training your body to transfer energy efficiently.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Sink into the ground using your back leg, holding tension until you swing. 

Turn (coil) into your back hip and unload that coil into the ball.

Consistency is everything in baseball. 

If you can cover pitches low and away, you'll force the pitcher to throw the ball over the plate.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Practice backspinning this pitch in the air. 

You'll build good direction in your swing and be able to adjust to breaking balls low and in as well.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Most pitchers will try to get you out using the bottom half of the zone. 

Train your swing to cover low pitches and you'll make pitchers uncomfortable on the mound.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
You shouldn't have any extra movements after your front foot hits the ground. 

This drill helps you build tension and rotate directly to the ball without any wasted movement.
Skills: Power, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Your load and rotation to the ball should be powerful and directed up the middle of the field. 

Train yourself to load and rotate explosively using your big muscles (hips, core and legs) instead of your arms and shoulders.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Drill Name: Medball Throws from Chest - Launch Position
Description:
You shouldn't have any extra movements after your front foot hits the ground. 

This drill helps you build tension and rotate directly to the ball without any wasted movement.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs, Timing

Description:

Train yourself to load and rotate explosively using your big muscles (hips, core and legs) instead of your arms and shoulders.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Drill Name: Medball Throws from Hip - Launch Position
Description:
You shouldn't have any extra movements after your front foot hits the ground. 

This drill helps you build tension and rotate directly to the ball without any wasted movement.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs, Timing
