Train yourself to load and rotate explosively using your big muscles (hips, core, and legs) instead of your arms and shoulders.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Practice backspinning the ball while keeping your effort level around 50-60%. 

The best players can hit this pitch perfectly every rep.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Practice backspinning the ball while keeping your effort level around 50-60%. 

The best players can hit this pitch perfectly every rep.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Keeping your hands above the ball and squaring this pitch up trains the same bat path you need to hit high velocity. 

Keep your effort level low and focus on making good contact.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Practice backspinning the ball while keeping your effort level around 50-60%. 

The best players can hit this pitch perfectly every rep.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description: Watch Mike Trout sink into his front leg to adjust to an offspeed pitch and then hit through spin by driving his backside.
Skills: Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description: Think North - South instead of East - West with your swing.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball

Description:
Using your back leg to control your swing lets you stay athletic and adjustable in the box. 

Loading directly into your back hip builds power that you can easily transfer into contact.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Your load should be a controlled way to get in a powerful position to hit. 

Be an athlete.

Try this adjustment if you're popping the ball up or feel like you lunge forward in games. 

Stay loaded in your back hip and turn to the ball.
Skills: Contact, Staying Back, Timing, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Pulling off the ball?

Start by fixing your finish.

Hands finishing high — not down by your side.

Helps with:
• Staying through the ball
• Better direction
• More consistent contact

Gives you much more room to be off time and still drive the ball 💪

Like always, stay athletic.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Pulling the ball does not mean forcing it or changing your swing. 

Catch the ball out in front of the zone while taking a normal swing. 

If your bat path is where it should be, then you'll hit the ball to the pull side for a line drive.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Don't change your swing when hitting inside pitches. 

Keep your turn tight and catch the ball out in front of your body.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
If you feel rushed at the plate or having trouble staying through the ball, remember this feel. 

Your body should rotate while you keep your hand working to the middle of the field.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball

Description:
Moving slowly through your swing makes it obvious if you're pulling off, spinning or drifting forward. 

These reps should feel slow and direct to the middle of the field.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
This drill is direct feedback on where your energy goes as you swing. 

You should throw your PVC pipe or bat in the air to the middle of the field. 

Your swing should feel smooth and easy.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
If you're pushing your hands to the ball or spinning off, this feel helps you rotate to contact using your hips and core.

Stay through the middle of the field.

You should feel balanced and in control during these reps.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Build the feel of adjusting to offspeed pitches by sinking slightly into your legs rather than drifting your upper body forward. 

You’re training your swing to adjust to the different speeds and locations you’ll see in games.
Skills: Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
Feel yourself moving north to south, not east to west. 

Rollovers are caused by the barrel entering and leaving the zone inefficiently.

Control your weight using your back hip and glute, holding tension in those muscles as you move forward. 

A slow and controlled stride allows you to get your best swing off in games, even when you aren’t perfectly on time. 

This helps you make better contact and adjust to different pitches.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
A powerful rotation is efficient and tight as you turn to the ball. 

Drive your back hip through the baseball.

When you load, your upper body and lower body should move opposite each other in order to generate the most power. 

Feeling your elbow move backwards as you stride forward puts your body in position to impact the ball with more power.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
A scissor kick can naturally happen as your body adjusts to different pitches. 

Training the move helps you stay through the ball and make a tighter, more efficient turn to contact.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Train yourself to stay grounded as you hit the ball and control the timing of your swing. 

These reps should be at 50-60% and result in low line drives to the middle of the field.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
Train yourself to stay grounded as you hit the ball and control the timing of your swing. 

These reps should be at 50-60% and result in low line drives to the middle of the field.
Skills: Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
If you have trouble staying consistent or hitting the ball hard, usually you aren't using your legs properly during your swing. 

Starting in your legs is an easy way to be more balanced and consistent at the plate.
Skills: Power, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Build your bat path to stay on plane with the pitch as long as possible so that you don't need perfect timing to have success. 

If you're rolling over, dragging your barrel, or pulling off the ball, remember this feel and apply it in your games.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Keeping your feet grounded forces your hands to be direct to the ball and work through the middle of the field. 

Stay athletic and in your legs, letting your bat work straight to the ball.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Build your bat path to stay on plane with the pitch as long as possible so that you don't need perfect timing to have success. 

If you're rolling over, dragging your barrel, or pulling off the ball, remember this feel and apply it in your games.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Loading your back hip allows you to transfer the most energy into the ball at contact. 

After you step back and load, keep tension in your back hip as you stride forward.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Loading your back hip allows you to transfer the most energy into the ball at contact. 

After you step back and load, keep tension in your back hip as you stride forward.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Control your stride using your back leg. 

If you stay back and keep your direction to the middle of the field, you'll be able to adjust to different pitches and get your best swings off during the game.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
In order for your bat to accelerate to contact, your legs and hips have to stop rotating. 

Your bat speed depends on how quickly you can stop your lower half. 

Build the feel of swinging hard while staying through the middle of the field.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back

Description:
In order for your bat to accelerate to contact, your legs and hips have to stop rotating. 

Your bat speed depends on how quickly you can stop your lower half. 

Build the feel of swinging hard while staying through the middle of the field.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back

Description:
Build rhythm into your swing and control when you make contact, rather than drifting into the ball. 

As you stride, your hands and front foot should work in opposite directions in order for your body to sequence your swing properly.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
If you're casting, flying open, or have a long swing, this drill will improve your bat path to be tighter and more efficient to contact. 

You should hit the ball backspun, back up the middle of the field.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Controlling your stride is how you adjust to different pitches and make great contact without needing to have perfect timing. 

Move slow and controlled so that you're never rushed when facing a pitcher and can get your best swings off.
Skills: Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Your rhythm and timing allow you to adjust to different speeds and locations of pitches. 

Build rhythm into your swing, stay loose and athletic at the plate.
Skills: Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
Your top hand controls your barrel and how you impact the baseball. 

One-hand swings build the muscle memory you need to trust your hand path in games, when you need to adjust to different speeds and locations.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Your top hand controls your barrel and how you impact the baseball. 

One hand swings build the muscle memory you need to trust your hand path in games, when you need to adjust to different speeds and locations.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
This tee location is a good test if you're lunging forward or spinning off. 

Keep your hands up and stay through the ball while keeping your legs grounded.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
This tee location tests the first half of your swing and how tight you can turn to contact. 

Your reps should be below 80% and result in low, backspun line drives.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Hitting the ball up the middle does not mean forcing it or changing your swing. 

Catch the ball inside of your front foot while taking a normal swing. 

If your bat path is where it should be, then you'll hit the ball to the middle for a line drive.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Build rhythm into your swing and control when you make contact, rather than drifting into the ball. 

As you stride, your hands and front foot should work in opposite directions in order for your body to sequence your swing properly.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
You need to be able to stop your rotation just as quickly as you can start it. 

Use your core to remain stable without losing your balance.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Generating power in your swing comes both from rotating fast and stopping your rotation at the right time. 

As you get close to contact, use your core to stop your rotation as quickly as possible.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Generating power in your swing comes both from rotating fast and stopping your rotation at the right time. 

As you get close to contact, use your core to stop your rotation as quickly as possible.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Drill Name: What to Feel When You Stride
Description:
Build a stretch in your body as you stride forward. 

Your hands and front foot should work opposite each other so you build power in your launch position.

The position your body's in at the pitcher's release needs to be powerful and athletic.

Be ready to get your best swing off.

Avoid letting the barrel dump behind you.

When the barrel drops too early, it lags in the zone and makes it harder to square balls up.
By keeping the barrel flat through the hitting zone, you give yourself the most opportunity to make clean contact and drive the ball.

Get the bat in the zone early and keep it on plane.

When the back shoulder and bat work together, you stay through the ball longer and give yourself more room for error.
This allows you to square up more pitches and drive the ball with consistency.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back

Description:
Get the barrel in the zone early with a tight turn.

Avoid dumping the barrel behind you, which causes it to drag and leads to mishits.
Instead, keep the barrel on plane and extend through after contact to drive the ball with power and consistency.

Staying steady on your back leg helps with your timing and direction to the middle of the field. 

If you're lunging forward or off balance, use this feel to recenter yourself and control your swing with your back leg.
Skills: Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Training yourself to stay in your legs and keep your head level as you swing will build power and more consistent contact. 

Make sure you aren't drifting your upper body forward and instead stay in between your legs as you rotate to the ball.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
If you're casting, have a long swing, or are getting jammed, remember the feel from this drill. 

Choking up on the bat forces you to be direct to the ball with no wasted movement.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
If you're popping up, have low bat speed, or can't pull the ball in the air, practice getting your barrel out in front of your hands. 

Build bat speed and hit against your front side without drifting.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Train your body to swing hard without muscling up with your shoulders and arms. 

Your legs, hips, and core are your most powerful muscles, so use them to impact the ball.

Train your body to fully rotate through the baseball while staying balanced. 

Your swing should feel smooth and loose in games, and this drill helps your body build that feel.
Skills: Power, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
When your front foot hits the ground, you should feel powerful and balanced. 

You need to be able to adjust to different speeds and locations from your launch position without having to load again before swinging.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Starting with your leg in the air forces you to control your load and stride with your back hip. 

Sink into your hip as you move forward. 

Controlling your swing from your back leg helps with your timing, power, and adjusting to different pitches.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Swing Decisions

Description:
A scissor kick can naturally happen as your body adjusts to different pitches. 

Training the move helps you stay through the ball and make a tighter, more efficient turn to contact.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Build your bat path to stay on plane with the pitch as long as possible so that you don't need perfect timing to have success. 

If you're rolling over, dragging your barrel, or pulling off the ball, remember this feel and apply it in your games.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Keeping your feet grounded forces your hands to be direct to the ball and work through the middle of the field. 

Stay athletic and in your legs, letting your bat work straight to the ball.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Loading your back hip allows you to transfer the most energy into the ball at contact. 

After you step back and load, keep tension in your back hip as you stride forward.
Skills: Power, Timing, Staying Back, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
In order for your bat to accelerate to contact, your legs and hips have to stop rotating. 

Your bat speed depends on how quickly you can stop your lower half. 

Build the feel of swinging hard while staying through the middle of the field.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Through the Ball, Staying Back

Description:
Your top hand controls your barrel and how you impact the baseball. 

One hand swings build the muscle memory you need to trust your hand path in games, when you need to adjust to different speeds and locations.
Skills: Power, Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs

Description:
Your bottom hand determines the direction of your swing. 

Train yourself to stay through the ball to the middle of the field. 

Keep your front shoulder pointed toward the pitcher as long as you can.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed

Description:
Posture over the plate is key to staying on the ball.

If your head and chest pull away, you’ll roll off and lose power.

By keeping posture over the plate, you stay stacked, drive through the ball, and can hit to all parts of the field.
Skills: Contact, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Staying Back

Description:
A proper tee warmup sets the tone for your round.

If you take full swings right away, you risk blowing out the tank too early.

By starting with a simple warmup progression and building into full swings, you stay loose, find rhythm, and get the most out of your work.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Back, Staying Through the Ball, Hitting Offspeed, Hitting Fastballs, Swing Decisions

Description:
One-hand tee work helps train connection in the swing.

If your hand casts or reaches, you get disconnected and lose power.

By keeping the hand connected to your back shoulder, you stay tight, on plane, and drive through the ball.
Skills: Power, Contact, Timing, Staying Back, Staying Through the Ball

Description:
Build strength in the same muscles you use as your arm enters layback when throwing. 

Lie on your side with your top arm bent 90°, hold a dumbbell, and rotate your forearm upward while keeping your elbow glued to your side. 

Control the lowering phase and feel your shoulder engage.

Lie on your side, hold a dumbbell in the top hand, and “punch” it straight forward in front of your body. 

Keep your elbow tucked in and core braced—this builds shoulder strength and control.

Hold a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height, brace your core, then press it straight up until your arm is locked out and rotate your body. 

Lower it back down under control, focusing on wrist alignment and a smooth path—this builds strength and shoulder stability.

Stand tall holding a kettlebell in one hand, keep your elbow at 90 degrees in front of your shoulder and your wrist straight, then walk slowly. 

Focus on keeping your shoulder stable and your torso upright—this challenges shoulder strength and core control.

Hold a dumbbell, plate or kettlebell in one hand at your side, stand tall, and walk forward while preventing your torso from leaning. 

Keep your shoulder down and your core tight—this reinforces grip strength, shoulder stability, and core strength.

Hold baseballs or weighted balls to make this more challenging. 

Keep your head neutral and squeeze your upper back—this improves shoulder mobility and back strength.

Stand with your back against a wall, elbows bent at 90° and forearms pressed against the wall. 

Slide your arms up and down while pressing your forearms and lower back against the wall.

You can use a foam roller, towel or any object that you can roll against the wall. 

Keeping your core tight, press your forearms up and down without moving your shoulders.

Place your forearm against a wall at shoulder height, rotate until you feel a gentle stretch across your chest, and hold. 

Keep your shoulder blade down and your chest square—this helps with shoulder mobility.

Hold baseballs or weighted balls to make this more challenging. 

Move slowly and focus on squeezing your shoulder blades—this strengthens your shoulder and scaps.
Skills: Arm Strength, Recovery, Activation, Injury Prevention

Description:
Use your shoulder to externally rotate, lift the ball up in the air and catch it on the way down. 

Make sure your elbow stays at shoulder height the entire time and you keep the rest of your body stable.

Strengthen your shoulder to handle a higher amount of force as you throw. 

Facing away from a wall or net, use your scap and shoulder to throw the ball backwards with your eyes following your hand. 

You should feel this movement start with your scaps.

Keep your elbow at 90 degrees and tucked at your side. 

Use your shoulder to rotate up and throw the ball, catching it on the way down. 

Build rhythm, keeping your elbow in the same position the entire time.

Hold baseballs or weighted balls to make this more challenging. 

Keep your arms fully extended and at shoulder height the entire time. 

Move slowly and get as many drops in as you can each round.

Anchor a band at shoulder height, then pull down your arms into an “A” shape. 

Keep your core tight and arms extended—this strengthens your upper back and improves shoulder stability.

With the band anchored low, lift your arms into a “Y” above your head. 

Maintain full-arm extension and feel your scaps engage—this helps with shoulder and back strength.

Use your scaps to pull your elbows back, keeping them at shoulder height before rotating your arms and pressing up. 

Biggest thing is to keep your elbows at or above shoulder height without leaning back using your body.

Anchor the band at elbow height, hold it with your elbow bent to 90° at your side, and rotate your forearm away from your body. 

Keep your elbow glued to your hip the whole time.

Hold a light kettlebell, lay on your back and raise your arm to a 90 degree angle. 

Maintain tension in your tricep and push your lower back against the ground to engage your core.

Anchor the band at elbow height, stand sideways to it and hold the band with your elbow bent at 90°.

Internally rotate your forearm toward your stomach. 

Maintain a stable elbow position and keep the rest of your body still.
Skills: Arm Strength, Recovery, Activation, Injury Prevention

Description:
Keep your legs and core stable as you move your arm backwards in a circle. 

Make the first move back explosive. 

You're training your shoulder to handle higher amounts of force in your motion.
Skills: Arm Strength, Recovery, Activation, Injury Prevention

Description:
Keep your elbow at shoulder height and use your shoulder to rotate your forearm up. 

You shouldn't move any other part of your body during the exercise. 

You're strengthening your shoulder's ability to externally rotate, matching the position when your arm is in layback.
Skills: Arm Strength, Recovery, Activation, Injury Prevention

Description:
Keep your elbow at shoulder height and use your shoulder to rotate your forearm down. 

You shouldn't move any other part of your body during the exercise. 

This strengthens your shoulder's ability to internally rotate, matching the position as you release the ball.
Skills: Arm Strength, Recovery, Activation, Injury Prevention

Description:
Sit upright with your core tight and extend the band so there's tension throughout your entire rep. 

Bring your arms down to a field goal position and raise them back up. 

You're strengthening your shoulders, scaps and back muscles.

Kneel upright with your core tight and extend the band so there's tension throughout your entire rep. 

Bring your arms down to a field goal position and raise them back up. 

You're strengthening your shoulders, scaps and back muscles.

Lay prone on the ground with two weights or small objects in line with your lower chest. 

With your arms extended, raise them over the object, touch the ground and return to the other side. 

You're strengthening your body awareness, shoulders and scaps.

Lay prone on the ground with two weights or small objects in line with your head. 

With your arms extended, raise them over the object, touch the ground and return to the other side. 

You're strengthening your body awareness, shoulders and scaps.

With your hands behind your back, rapidly stretch the band out and in while keeping your arms extended. 

You're training your shoulders to move fast, explosive and controlled.

Lay prone on the ground with two weights or small objects in line with your shoulders. 

With your arms extended, raise them over the object, touch the ground and return to the other side. 

You're strengthening your body awareness, shoulders and scaps.

Loop a band around your foot and raise it up to shoulder height with your arm fully extended. 

You're strengthening your shoulder muscles and stability.

Hold baseballs, weighted balls or light weights to make this more challenging. 

Keep your back tight and squeeze the trap muscles at the top. 

This movement should be slow and controlled.

Hold baseballs or weighted balls to make this more challenging. 

Keep the elbow bent at 90 degrees. 

Do not lose posture as your shoulders start burning.

Hold light weights and move slowly through each position. 

This will work your entire arm and bring blood flow to your elbow.

Use light weights and keep your arms straight as you move betwen each position. 

Move slow and controlled so you strengthen the little muscles in your arms.

You can use a J Band or exercise band. 

Pull apart the band by squeezing your upper back. 

Pause briefly at the top to get the most out of this movement.

Strengthening your triceps helps protect your elbow and allows the joint to handle higher amounts of force when you throw. 

This is a great pre throw drill.

Strengthen your chest in it's full range of motion. 

Pinch your scaps back and then use your chest to bring your hands together out in front of your body.

Don't let your elbow move as you turn the weight over. 

Keep the weight light and control the movement as you rotate to each side.

Turn your thumbs in so they face your body. 

Use the outside of your shoulder to lift your arms to shoulder height and slowly lower back down.

Keep your chest tall, arms at 90 degrees the entire time. 

With your elbows still, slowly rotate your forearms down and up.

Slowly put pressure on your tricep and bicep. 

As you roll your arm, press deeper into the muscle and move your arm around to hit all angles of your muscles.
test
test

Hold a PVC Pipe, bat or any other long object in your hands. 

While kneeling on the ground with your elbows on an elevated surface in front of you, press your chest towards the floor and hands towards your back. 

You should feel this in your shoulders and lats, lengthening the backside of your arms.

Drill Name: Pushup to Downward Dog Toe Touch
Description:
From a pushup position, press your trunk up into downward dog, and keep your core strong as you touch opposite hand to foot. 

Remember to breathe, building strength and range of motion in your shoulders and core.

Strength and mobility in your shoulders helps you throw harder while keeping your arm healthy. 

Do these as a warmup before throwing or recovery for your shoulder.

Hold a medicine ball or any other weighted object in your hands. 

You need strength and range of motion in your upper back in order to generate the most power on the field. 

Control your weight using your core as you extend back and exhale on the way up.

Strength and mobility in your forearms helps you throw harder while keeping your arm healthy. 

Do these as a warmup before throwing.

Push your elbow back without moving your shoulders. 

Exhale into the stretch and try to raise your elbow up as high as you can.

Lay prone on the ground with a light band below your waist, holding it at the ends. 

Raise your chest, legs, and hands off the ground while maintaining tension in your band. 

You're strengthening your back, adding range of motion to your spine.

Lock out your elbows at the top to get a full range of motion. 

Slowly move between each position, exhaling as you press into your bridge.

Begin in a half-kneeling position, band set up high off the ground. 

Lean your chest forward as you row, pulling straight down and extending straight up.

If your arm's sore, don't rely on quick fixes. 

Consistently follow a pre throw routine in order to improve your arm pain and keep it strong in the future.

You should be ready to go before the team's warmup starts. 

Don't use catch play to get your arm ready.

Drill Name: Dealing with Arm Pain at Practice
Description:
A prethrow routine allows you to keep practicing even when your arm is sore. 

During practice use your full body to throw, using your legs and building momentum into each throw.

Find what your body responds the best to and stick to it. 

Recovery allows you to move on from the day and start preparing for your next time on the field.

You abuse the same muscles over and over when you throw. 

Target the muscles that slow your arm down and strengthen them in order to stay healthy.

Drill Name: What a Post Throw Routine Looks Like
Description:
Be thorough and consistent each time after you throw. 

Move your arm and bring blood flow to all of the areas you use to throw.

Tight and weak forearms will lead to elbow pain. 

These muscles are typically neglected and are just as important as any other part of your arm.

Strengthen the areas surrounding the front of your shoulder in order to address discomfort. 

Follow the exercises before and after every time you throw.

Get your arm moving and draw blood flow to all parts of your arm. 

Keeping your arm still will allow it to swell up.

Prepare for practice and your games by activating the muscles you use to throw. 

From your core, legs and arms make sure they are warmed up ready to go.

Stop cheating your reps by using the rest of your body. 

Only use the muscles you're supposed to, squeeze at the top and control your movement on the way down.
Skills: Recovery, Arm Strength, Injury Prevention, Activation

Drill Name: Get the Most Out of Band Work
Description:
Stop rushing through your reps. 

Control your eccentric movement and lengthen your muscles.
Skills: Recovery, Arm Strength, Injury Prevention, Activation

Description:
The movement needs to come from your shoulder, elbow staying still at 90 degrees. 

It's easy to move your entire body to compensate, if it's too hard just step closer to the band.
Skills: Recovery, Arm Strength, Injury Prevention, Activation

Description:
Jump straight up and down keeping your toes up. 

You're building rhythm, coordination, and lower-leg reactivity—key for quick, explosive movement.

Keep your feet together as you jump forward and backward. 

Your upper body should stay in the same place with only your legs moving.

Keep your feet together as you jump side to side. 

Your upper body should stay in the same place with only your legs moving.

Jump and switch your feet each rep with one landing in front of the other. 

Make sure you're jumping in place and aren't shifting side to side.

With one foot in front of the other, jump straight up and down. 

Keep your chest tall and core strong so you don't lean forward or side to side.

Keep your posture tall and knee up to waist height each rep. 

Drive the ball of your foot into the ground, helping build proper sprint mechanics.

Move your leg in a cycle motion in rhythm with your skips. 

By snapping your leg down after the knee drive, you're training your body to apply more force with each stride.

B‑Marches build strength, coordination, and sprint mechanics in a slower, controlled way. 

Snapping the leg down after extension trains you to apply force into the ground, which is key for running with power and efficiency.

Resisted starts build explosive first‑step power. 

The band adds resistance, forcing you to push harder and develop the strength and mechanics needed to get out fast when it matters most.

Terminal knee extensions strengthen the muscles around your knee to improve stability during sprinting and direction changes. 

Squeezing your quad at the top builds control and helps protect your knee from injury.

Standing tall next to the wall, cycle your leg from knee up to contact with the ground. 

You should feel a swiping motion against the ground.

C‑Skips improve hip mobility and coordination, helping your legs move more freely and efficiently when you sprint. 

The rhythm of the movement trains better control and timing, which leads to smoother, faster running mechanics.

Build efficient sprint mechanics by teaching your legs to strike under your body with speed and control. 

Gaining speed through each rep trains proper rhythm, force application, and coordination for faster sprinting.

Combine quick foot speed with powerful stride mechanics to improve sprint timing and rhythm. 

Transitioning from dribbles to B‑Skips helps you connect fast, reactive steps to the bigger, more forceful motions used in top‑speed running.

Trains explosive power and body control by combining lateral movement with a quick transition into sprinting. 

Sticking the landing helps build balance, while the sprint trains you to accelerate out of sharp changes in direction—just like in a game.

Builds single‑leg power and quickness by loading the outside leg and exploding into a fast knee switch. 

This helps you generate force off one leg and improves hip control—key for sprint starts and sharp changes of direction.

Trains hip mobility, coordination, and footwork—especially for movements like drop steps and changing angles in the field. 

Staying low and leading with your hips builds better control and quicker transitions in game‑like situations.

Builds explosive lateral power and improves your ability to change direction quickly. 

Starting from a kneeling position forces you to push hard off the ground, mimicking the kind of reaction and burst you need in game situations.

Develops lateral speed, rhythm, and body control by training you to move powerfully and smoothly sideways. 

Staying soft on your landings while driving your arms helps build coordination and athletic movement in all directions.

Trains the arm mechanics and rhythm needed for efficient sprinting. 

Moving fast and tight with proper form helps your upper body stay in sync with your legs, which is key for running with speed and control.

Build rhythm and posture while pushing off your back leg and cover more ground with each stride.

Drive your knees and push through the ground each step.

Train explosive hip action and leg drive, which are key for sprint starts and acceleration. 

Rotating quickly and switching knees builds coordination, power, and the ability to fire your hips efficiently when you take off.

Keeping your upper body stable while your legs move fast trains coordination, rhythm, and the explosive mechanics needed for sprinting. 

Make sure you keep putting force into the wall as you drive your legs.

Driving your knee up against resistance trains the same motion you use when accelerating, while controlling the return improves stability and control. 

Keep a forward lean as you drive out with good posture in your upper body.

Keeping your upper body still while your legs move quickly helps build the control and rhythm needed for explosive acceleration. 

Push hard into the ground through the balls of your feet, knees getting to waist height.

Lateral Ladder In & Out drills build quickness, coordination, and body control while moving side to side. 

Staying low and syncing your arms with your feet trains efficient movement and rhythm—key for fielding and changing direction in games.

Improve coordination, foot speed, and body control during lateral movement. 

Taking quick, choppy steps between hurdles trains your feet to stay active while keeping your rhythm smooth and controlled.

Build coordination, foot speed, and rhythm while moving laterally. 

By staying light on your feet and repeating precise patterns, you train your body to move quickly and efficiently.

Improve lateral quickness, coordination, and body control. 

Staying low and stepping with one foot per rung helps train fast, efficient movement and sharp direction changes—key for reacting on the field.

Lateral Cone Shuffles train explosive side-to-side movement and the ability to stop and change direction quickly. 

Staying low and taking powerful steps helps build control, while active arm movement keeps your rhythm sharp and balanced.

Wall Sprints help build explosive sprint mechanics by training powerful knee drive and proper body position. 

Keep your upper body forward with your weight pushing against the wall.

A Marches help reinforce sprinting mechanics in a slow, controlled way so you can build good habits. 

Focusing on “knee up, toe up, heel under” trains proper posture, arm drive, and leg position for efficient sprinting.

Posture in your running form is crucial to reach your top speed. 

Start with your hands overhead and hold your posture upright as you run, making cyclical strides with your legs.

Skips for Distance help build lower-body power and teach you how to push through the ground with each stride. 

Covering more ground trains full stride extension, which is key for improving sprint speed.

Backpedal to Dropstep trains quick directional changes by simulating game-like reactions. 

Dropping your foot and turning into a sprint helps you stay low, explode out, and transition smoothly from defense to acceleration.

Single A Pauses improve balance, posture, and control by forcing you to hold your knee up before switching. 

Slowing it down helps lock in sprint mechanics and strengthens the muscles used for powerful knee drive.

Straight Leg Bounds help build hamstring strength and teach you how to apply force into the ground without bending your knees. 

Covering as much ground as possible each step trains powerful, efficient stride mechanics for top-end sprinting.

Ladder Single Leg Footwork helps improve rhythm, coordination, and balance while moving forward. 

The quick steps followed by a controlled ladder touch train your body to stay in sync and under control—key for smooth, athletic movement.

Ladder Step Behind Footwork builds coordination, rhythm, and body control while moving laterally. 

Stepping behind trains you to stay balanced and controlled through complex footwork—great for improving agility and movement precision.

Training your feet to be light and move in rhythm allows you to move quicker on the field. 

Keep your feet moving as you transition between dribbles and use your momentum to carry you forward.

How much force your body can absorb determines how much power you can put into the ground. 

Stay balanced and stable as you drop onto your foot.
test
test

One foot stays on the floor and the other foot is against the wall behind you, then lean your hips forward. 

Stay strong in your glutes. 

You should feel a big stretch in the front of your hip—this opens up your hip flexors.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Stand tall with feet hip-width, hands on your hips, then bend at your waist like you’re bowing. 

Keep your back straight and knees soft—this stretches your hamstrings and lower back.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Stand on one leg and move your other hip in a big circle without letting your body twist. 

Go slow and control every part of the circle—this makes your hip strong and mobile.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Lay your ankle over your knee and sit down like you're sitting into a chair. 

Stay balanced and stable in this position as you hold the stretch, opening up your hips and glutes.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Exhale as you press into the stretch, chest over your knee. 

You should feel this stretch in your glute and hip.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Hip mobility and range of motion allows you to get the most out of your body in games while staying healthy. 

Keep your down leg pinned to the ground and externally rotate your other leg as high as you can each rep.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Step one foot forward like a runner, place both hands next to that foot, and lower your hips, then twist your chest toward your front leg. 

Switch sides after a few seconds—this stretches hips, hamstrings, and your back all at once.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
Stand next to a low bench or chair, lift one leg over and place it on the other side, then step back down. 

Keep your chest tall—this helps your hips and hamstrings move better.
Skills: Acceleration, Top Speed, Sprinting Form, Agility

Description:
This is important for building good hands and clean footwork. 

Make sure you stay low and work through the ball to simulate a real game rep.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
Work on beating the ball to the spot and fielding backhands on the move. 

Working through the ball helps carry your momentum toward first, making your throw stronger and more accurate.

Quick, choppy steps help you stay athletic and in control as you move through the ball. 

The momentum you build makes your throw to first smoother and more powerful.

This drill simulates a backhand play with your left foot in front of your right. 

It helps you work on reach, balance, and getting your feet set quickly for the throw. 

Practice multiple types of backhands because you never know which one you’ll need in a game.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
This drill simulates a backhand play with your left foot in front of your right. 

Practicing different types of backhands is key because you never know which one you’ll need in a game.

Sometimes you’ll have to reach out and field the ball outside your body. 

This drill helps you stay in rhythm, control your body, and get into a strong position to throw.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
Great for working on tough hops that bounce high off the dirt. 

Focus on staying low, timing the bounce, and moving through the ball to make a clean pick and strong finish.
Skills: On the Run, Short Hops, Footwork

Description:
Helps you isolate glove work and feel the proper backhand motion without using your legs. 

Stay smooth and work through the ball to mimic a real backhand pick.

Great for isolating your glove side and building clean forehand mechanics. 

Focus on working through the ball with your glove.

Builds clean glove fundamentals by keeping you centered and using two hands through the ball. 

Make sure to field the ball as soon as it bounces to limit bad hops on a real field.

Helps you work on staying low and athletic while fielding the ball out front. 

It simplifies ground balls and simulates what you'd do on a real field—attacking short hops and moving through the play with control.

Gets you ready to move quickly and cover ground for extended backhands. 

The prep step simulates how you’d react in a game, helping you stay light on your feet and ready to make the play.

Trains your first movement to be quick and controlled when fielding forehands. 

Staying light on your feet helps you react in rhythm and get into a good position to make the play.

Helps you stay athletic and ready to move right before the ball is hit. 

This simulates a clean middle play where you field out front and shuffle through the throw.

Builds a quick first move into a backhand while keeping you in rhythm. 

Helps simulate the footwork and angle needed to field cleanly and move through the throw toward first.

Sharpens your pre-pitch movement so you're ready to react in any direction. 

Landing on the balls of your feet keeps you balanced, athletic, and quick to move.

Pick your hop, attack it, and then set your feet to throw to first. 

This drill helps you field in between plays where you charge the ball and still have time to set your feet for your throw.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description: Works on beating the ball to your backhand side and staying in rhythm through the play. Beating the ball to the spot is key—it helps you get set early, field cleanly, and avoid tough hops. If you don’t have someone to hit ground balls, use a wall or have a partner toss a ball to your backhand side.

Simulates a backhand where you don’t have time to beat the ball to the spot or work through it. 

If you don’t have someone to hit ground balls, use a wall or have a partner roll the ball to your backhand side.

Simulates a double play feed from second base using an open-side turn. 

Focus on fielding clean, getting your feet in position, and lining up your body for a quick, accurate throw to second. 

If you don’t have someone to hit ground balls, use a wall or have a partner help. 

To take it a step further, set up a target that represents the shortstop’s left shoulder and aim to hit it every time.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
Simulates a double play feed from shortstop with a clean throw to second base. 

Focus on staying low, fielding out front, and making a quick, accurate throw. 

If you don’t have someone to hit ground balls, have a partner roll balls to you or use a wall. 

This is just one of many double play feeds—it’s important to practice them all. 

To take it a step further, set up a target that represents the second baseman’s left shoulder and try to hit it every time.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
Simulates a toss from second base to start a double play.

Focus on fielding clean, staying low, and making a smooth, accurate toss to the shortstop.

If you don’t have someone to hit ground balls, have a partner roll balls to you or use a wall.

This is just one of many double play feeds—it’s important to practice them all. 

To take it a step further, set up a target that represents the shortstop’s left shoulder and try to hit it every time.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
Helps with making quick, clean tags on short hops at second or third base. 

Stay low, pick the ball smoothly, and snap the tag in one tight, controlled motion.

This forces you to hunt the short hop. 

As it is in the air, read the hop and then attack, fielding it right after the ball bounces again.

Helps you build smooth, efficient footwork for double play turns at shortstop. 

Focus on timing your steps so you catch with your left foot down and swipe your right foot around the bag for a quick transfer and throw. 

To take it a step further, try practicing with different types of feeds—don’t rely on perfect throws to the chest. 

Challenge yourself to adjust and still complete the turn.

Drill Name: SS Set Up Early Double Play
Description:
It is important to set up early as a target for plays in which your teammate has a tough throw. 

Setting up early allows you to move around the bag if the throw is off target while also giving him a huge focal point to look at.

Prep step and then move quickly to your glove side. 

After the catch, replace your feet quickly toward your target.

Keep this move simple. 

Pick the ball aggressively, but be sure to not extend too far so you can still get the tag down quickly.

This play is all based around a solid setup. 

Make sure you set up at the right time when you know where the last hop will land. 

Position your glove and hand on the right side of your body so you will have a quick, smooth transfer.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description: Attack this play by fielding the ball as you move closer and more in line with your target.
Keep your eyes behind the ball as you drop step, watching it all the way into your glove.
Keep your eyes behind the ball as you drop step, watching it all the way into your glove.

Use this play when you range into the hole. 

It will be easier to spin around and pick up your target than try to turn clockwise.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
You must attack these plays with full speed. 

If you do not, the runner may be safe and beat the throw down the line.
Skills: On the Run, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
This is used when the ball is hit close to you. 

After the catch, redirect the ball to second base.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
This catch play drill helps you build the muscle memory of relay throws, helping you be more comfortable throwing on the move. 

Start with your back to your target, take a couple backward shuffles, then turn and throw.

After you field the ground ball, your only job is to give the shortstop a good feed. 

Let the shortstop be quick during the turn.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Double Plays, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Drill Name: Dry Rep Slow Roller Footwork to Throw
Description:
Being in sync will cause this to look smooth. 

It is important to load the right hip to set up a strong throw.
Skills: On the Run, Short Hops, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
Reset your feet after the catch with a smooth shuffle. 

This will make the throw much easier and more on target.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
Reset your feet after the catch with a smooth shuffle. 

This will make the throw much easier and more on target.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description: Field the ball out in front of your body with one hand, practicing "picking" it.

Work up and through the ball. 

Do not let the ball get too close to you or it will handcuff you.

Work forward and up, turning your thumb slightly over the ball to trap it inside. 

The thumb turn is a very small movement but can be the difference maker between a clean catch or an error.

Drill Name: Balance Slow Roll Pick to Transfers
Description:
This is the second step of the slow roll sequence. 

Focus on a clean transition. 

If you can transfer it cleanly, it will allow you to take fewer steps before releasing the ball.
Skills: On the Run, Short Hops, Transfers

Description:
As you run toward it, work up and through the ball. 

Let your approach to the ball be very direct, or in a U-shape if you have extra time to ensure a quick throw.
Skills: On the Run, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description:
A lower arm slot will help on these throws so you do not have to stand all the way back up. 

Stay low, and aim up the line.
Skills: On the Run, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Drill Name: Dry Rep Backhand Spin to Throw
Description:
This play is used when the ball is hit hard to your backhand side. 

Use the ground as leverage to get up very quickly. 

Feel as if you are going with the ball and it will take you around.
Skills: Lateral Plays, Short Hops, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
Use this play when you recognize a short hop you can attack. 

You will pick the ball while landing on the same foot you pushed off from.
Skills: On the Run, Footwork, Transfers, Short Hops

Description: This is the first step of the slow roll sequence. Pick the ball cleanly.
Skills: On the Run, Short Hops, Transfers

Drill Name: Balance Slow Roll Picks to Throw
Description:
This is the third step of the slow roll sequence. 

After having a clean transfer, throw your hip to the target, aiming up the line.
Skills: On the Run, Short Hops, Transfers, Throws

Description: Step with your left foot on the bag as you catch the ball, and as you transfer, step off onto your right foot to throw.

Drill Name: 1B Playing In Footwork to the Bag
Description:
Set up in front of the base as if you are expecting a bunt. 

Take a prep step and then turn and sprint to first base. 

Set up with both of your feet on the base, ready for the throw.

Drill Name: 1B Playing Back Footwork to the Bag
Description:
Set up behind the base. 

Take a prep step and then turn and sprint to first base. 

Set up with both of your feet on the base, ready for the throw.

Drill Name: 1B Prep Step While Holding the Runner
Description:
Start on the base, holding the runner, and then take two shuffles away from the bag as the pitcher throws home. 

Time your footwork so your feet land as the ball crosses home plate.
Set up holding the runner on, shuffle off the base, and use your footwork to field the groundball while building momentum to second base and into your throw.

Drill Name: 1B Playing Back Force Out at First
Description:
With runners on base, your job as a first baseman is to field the ball cleanly, make the out at first and then immediately turn to face the infield in case a runner is trying to advance. 

Stay calm and under control the entire play.

Drill Name: 1B Playing In Force Out at First
Description:
With runners on base, your job as a first baseman is to field the ball cleanly, make the out at first and then immediately turn to face the infield in case a runner is trying to advance. 

Stay calm and under control the entire play.
Set up holding the runner on, shuffle off the base, and use your footwork to field the groundball while building momentum to second base and into your throw.

Set up holding the runner on, shuffle off the base, and use your footwork to field the groundball. 

After you field the ball, step on first with your arm-side leg, push off, and throw to second. 

Remember to communicate with your middle infielders—they now need to tag the runner out.

This drill will help you react to any throw in any location. 

Start with both feet square on the base. 

Use your footwork to extend out and field the ball, picking it in rhythm as far out from the bag as you can.
Get eye level with the ball and field it as close to the bounce as you can to limit the room for a bad bounce.
Get eye level with the ball and field it as close to the bounce as you can to limit the room for a bad bounce.

Drill Name: 1B Playing Back Double Play to Second
Description:
Position yourself back behind the base. 

If you're a right-handed fielder, field the groundball and flip your feet toward second base to throw. 

A left-handed first baseman will field the groundball and throw to second without needing to turn.

Position yourself deep behind the base. 

Field a groundball into the 4-hole and use your feet to build momentum back to the bag as you toss the pitcher the ball.

Position yourself behind the base and field a slow groundball that takes you in toward home plate. 

Stay low and keep your legs moving as you turn and toss the pitcher the ball.
Get to the bag early. You will step back when the ball is coming at you on target so you can quickly redirect toward first.
Work to the other side of the bag to gain momentum from the feed. Then redirect toward first.
Use your feet to transfer to the side of the bag the throw comes to so you have more range and a quicker catch.

Use your feet to set up on the middle of the base. 

As the throw comes in, slide to the arm side of the base, push out toward the throw, and make your catch. 

Time this so that your front foot lands in sync with catching the ball.

Use your feet to set up on the middle of the base. 

As the throw comes in, slide to the arm side of the base, push out toward the throw, and make your catch. 

Time this so that your front foot lands in sync with catching the ball.
Field the ball working up and through it instead of fielding it back toward you. This will eliminate bad hops.
Field the ball working forward and up, then turn the thumb slightly over to trap the ball.

Field the ball working through it and up. 

Do not let it get too close to your body or it will handcuff you.

This play is used when the ball is hit farther away from you. 

Stay low and keep your eyes behind the ball so you can watch it all the way in.
Field the ball working up and through it instead of fielding it back toward you. Then, bring it toward your chest and set your feet toward the target.

Field the ball working through it and up. 

Bring it to your chest as you set your feet toward the target. 

Do not let it get too close to your body or it will handcuff you.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description: This drill forces you to "pick" the ball out in front with two hands, then bring it to your chest as you shuffle forward.
Field the ball working up and through it instead of fielding it back toward you. This will eliminate bad hops.

Work up and through the ball. 

Do not let the ball get too close to you or it will handcuff you.

It all starts with your footwork, timing and rhythm. 

Gaining momentum through the ball will help you stay consistent and make better throws to first.
Field the ball out in front of your body first and then bring it to your chest as you gain momentum to first.

Drill Name: Master Your First Step in the Infield
Description:
Your first step makes or breaks the play. 

Control your timing so you're in the air as the batter makes contact with the ball.

Keep your eyes behind the ball and stay as low to the ground as you can. 

Use your feet to gain momentum back to first base.

Beat the ball to the spot as often as you can. 

Work around the ball so you can gain momentum to first base.

Keep your eyes behind the ball and then immediately replace your feet to gain momentum to first base. 

Stay low to the ground and as athletic as possible.

Use your feet to redirect your momentum to first base immediately after fielding the ball. 

Keep your eyes behind your glove, staying low to the ground.

Read the hop using your eyes and use your feet to attack the hop. 

Push through the ball with your glove, building momentum as you field it.
Skills: Short Hops, On the Run, Footwork, Transfers, Throws

Description: Get to the bag early, give your teammate a target and then replace your feet to throw to first.

Drill Name: First Base Footwork Coming Off the Bag
Description:
Navigating the bag starts with your feet. 

Crossover to reach a throw to your arm side and shuffle across the base to reach your glove side.

Work low and push through the ball. 

Give your teammates the confidence to throw it anywhere, knowing you'll make the out.

Always make sure you get an out. 

If you tag the bag before throwing to second, communicate with your teammates.

Recover from a bobble or miss play by using your barehand, rather than your glove. 

Don't panic or rush, pick the ball up cleanly.

Time your footwork to match your teammate's double play feed. 

Build momentum through the base and into your throw to first.
Skills: Short Hops, Lateral Plays, Footwork, Transfers

Description:
Beat the ball to the spot as often as you can. 

Set up with your eyes behind the ball, fielding the ball with one hand.
test

Use your lower half to create power on double play feeds.

When you rely only on your arm, the throw loses strength and accuracy.

By driving through the ball with your legs and hips, you build momentum that carries the ball firmly to your target

Always move your feet to create momentum on relay throws.

Catching the ball flat-footed makes it harder to get power and accuracy behind the throw.

By hopping into it and keeping your body in motion, you stay fluid and deliver a strong throw to your target..

Aiming the ball creates tightness and hesitation in your throw.

Throwing agressively under control allows muscle memory to take over, leading to smooth, consistent, and accurate throws.

Don’t move like a robot in the field.

Robotic movements are stiff, slow, and often keep you from making the right play.

Playing athletically lets your instincts take over, helping you react to the ball, adjust to hops, and move with speed and fluidity.

Play smooth and under control in the infield.

Rushing or moving too stiff makes routine plays harder than they need to be.

When you stay relaxed and fluid, the game slows down, and you can handle any hop with confidence.

Use your lowest arm slot when you don’t have time to stand all the way up to throw.

This is especially important on the run or during double plays, when quickness matters more than form.

By dropping your arm slot, you stay athletic and still deliver a strong, accurate throw under pressure.

Use an over the top arm angle when you need a direct throw to your target.

This slot creates backspin, which keeps the ball straight and accurate.

It’s especially useful on long throws, like from third base or during relay throws, when accuracy matters most.

Middle infielders often use a three quarter arm slot to for quickness and strength.

This slot lets you get the ball out fast while still keeping plenty of carry on the throw.

Since the ball will have some natural tail, it’s important to throw up the line to keep it on target.

Great infielders know how to throw from all three arm angles.

Over the top, three quarter, and low slots each serve a purpose depending on the play.

By practicing and trusting each one, you give yourself the best chance to make every throw on time and on target.

An option feed at second base should come from your legs, not just your arm.

When you extend only the elbow, the throw loses strength and accuracy.

By driving through the ball with your lower half, you create a powerful, controlled feed that sets up the double play.

Use your feet to build momentum on every relay throw.

If you catch the ball standing still, you lose power and accuracy.

By staying in motion and hopping into the throw, you stay smooth and drive the ball firmly to your target.

When turning a double play at shortstop, use your legs to generate power on the feed.

Relying only on your arm and elbow makes the throw weaker and slower.

By building momentum through the ball with your lower half, you create a strong, quick throw to the target.

When swiping across the bag, get to the very corner to stay out of the runner’s path.

Stepping on top of the base puts you in danger of getting taken out and blocks your throw.

By hitting the corner, you avoid contact and keep a clear lane to throw the ball.

Drill Name: Swiping Across the Bag Correctly Demo
Description:
When swiping across the bag, aim for the far corner to give yourself space from the runner.

Stepping straight on the base leaves you exposed to contact and makes the throw harder.

By working across the corner, you stay safe and keep your throwing lane wide open.

When setting up early for a double play, give the second baseman a big target to throw to.

This will help the 2B give an accurate feed.

By arriving early and putting your right foot on the corner of the base, you create a clear lane, stay out of the runner’s way, and make the turn clean.

Drill Name: Setting Up Early for DP Demo
Description:
When setting up early for a double play, give the second baseman a big target to throw to.

This will help the 2B give an accurate feed.

By arriving early and putting your right foot on the corner of the base, you create a clear lane, stay out of the runner’s way, and make the turn clean.

When making a tag at the bag, read the hop early to put yourself in the best position.

Go get the short hop to cut down the distance, but let the long hop travel into you.

By adjusting to the hop, you stay under control, secure the ball, and apply a clean tag.

When you decide to go pick the hop, keep your glove action quick and efficient.

Throwing the glove up high takes too much time to get back down to the bag.

By picking the ball clean and returning straight to the tag, you get the out fast.

Glove angle matters when fielding a groundball.

If your glove is facing up, the ball will bounce off and you won't field it cleanly.

By keeping the palm or “eye” of the glove facing the ball, you give yourself the biggest opportunity to field it cleanly.

On a groundball, you can’t funnel the ball in right away.

If you pull the ball in too soon, the ball may not go in the glove smoothly.

By picking the ball out front first, then funneling as you shuffle, you stay smooth and in rhythm to make the throw.

When fielding, start with your glove-side toes pointed up.

This positions your lower half to generate momentum as soon as you field the ball.

By setting up this way, your body naturally flows into the shuffle and keeps your feet quick and efficient.

When fielding, start with your glove-side toes pointed up.

This positions your lower half to generate momentum as soon as you field the ball.

By setting up this way, your body naturally flows into the shuffle and keeps your feet quick and efficient.

When throwing from a lower arm slot, don’t rely on your arm alone.

Load your hip first to generate power and momentum.

Like Nolan Arenado did in the video, gather the ball, load your hip, and fire for a strong, accurate throw.

Many players struggle with fear of failure, but mistakes are part of the game.

Fear makes your muscles tense, slows you down, and causes hesitation on plays.

By turning fear into excitement, you attack the ball, trust your instincts, and stay aggressive—like Bobby Witt Jr., who goes after every play with no hesitation.
Skills: Footwork, Transfers, Throws, Lateral Plays, Short Hops, First Base, Double Plays, On the Run

Description:
One-hand fielding is key for handling tough hops.

It allows you to take away the last hop or adjust with a quick drop step.

By training one hand plays, you stay athletic, control tough hops, and make plays smoother.
Skills: Short Hops, Footwork, Transfers, Lateral Plays, On the Run

Description:
Breaking your hands at the chest builds consistency in your throwing motion.

MLB players always catch the ball and bring it to their chest during catch play.

By repeating this move thousands of times, you build muscle memory that carries into every throw in the game.

As an infielder, you can’t float the ball across the diamond.

Field it clean, drive through with your legs, and fire a strong throw every time.

The double play starts with a clean feed.

A weak or off-target feed makes it almost impossible for your teammate to finish the turn.

By staying low, using your legs, and putting the ball on the chest, you set up your middle infielder to finish the play strong.

Correct footwork during double plays is key to being smooth and efficient.

If your steps are off, the timing of the turn is tough.

Backhands separate good infielders from great ones.

Stay low, angle through the ball, and trust your glove to secure it.
Skills: Footwork, Transfers, Lateral Plays, Short Hops

Description:
Improving your range starts with quick, explosive first steps.

By reading the ball early and staying on the move, you cover more ground and make more plays.

Fielding the forehand keeps you moving through the ball and into your throw.

Stay low, work through the hop, and use your momentum to make the play clean.

Drill Name: Fielding On the Run Plays Intro
Description:
Some of the toughest plays in the infield are made on the run.

By staying under control and using smooth footwork, you can field clean and throw accurately on the move.

Great infielders know how to find the right hop.

By attacking short hops or creating space for long hops, you give yourself the best chance to field the ball clean.

Infielders must learn to hunt the good hop.

By reading the ball early and adjusting your feet, you put yourself in position to field it clean every time.

Quick double plays come down to timing and rhythm.

By staying low, moving through the bag, and keeping the exchange fast, you give your team a chance to finish two.

Every infielder has to be able to handle short hops.

By staying low, soft with the glove, and working through the ball, you give yourself the best chance to pick it clean.

Lateral plays test your quickness and glove control.

By staying low, chopping your feet, andworking through the catch, you stay in rhythm and finish the play strong.

Infielders have to be able to move side to side explosively.

By staying low, keeping your feet active, and fielding through the ball, you cover ground and make tough plays look routine.

Drill Name: DP Feed - Correct Arm Slot Intro
Description:
Using the correct arm slot is key for a clean double play feed.

By staying low and keeping your arm in the proper slot, you deliver a quick, accurate toss your teammate can handle.

Double play feeds are all about timing and control.

By staying low, keeping your feet active, and using a clean arm slot, you set up your teammate to finish the turn quickly and accurately.

Accuracy is everything for an infielder.

By staying balanced, using your legs, and focusing on a consistent release, your throws will be on target.

First base footwork is all about working the corners of the bag.

By getting to the far edges, you give your team the best chance to make the out.

Working the bag at first base is key to fielding efficiently.

By moving to the corners, staying low, and keeping your feet active, you create better angles for throws and stay safe from the runner.

Footwork is key. 

Stretch out, work the corners, and stay athletic.

Quick infield relays are all about timing and communication.

By getting in position, staying low, and using momentum, you transfer the ball fast and give your teammates a chance to make the out.

Use your legs and feet to drive the throw.

Training your upper body to stay linear with your target builds the muscle memory that allows you to be consistent in games.

Description:

Skills: Velocity, Arm Path, Command, Hip Shoulder Separation, Lead Leg Block

If your upper and lower body don't move in sync during your delivery, the rest of your motion will be inconsistent and not sequenced properly.

A huge part of using your legs is creating a good angle for your hips to work down the mound, leading the rest of your body. 

This drill puts you in position to exaggerate leading with your hips, allowing you to generate more power down the mound.

Being in control during your delivery allows you to work in rhythm and be more consistent. 

This starts by controlling your leg lift and balance point, which this drill forces you to do.

Rotating your hips while keeping your upper body closed allows you to generate the most power, sequence your delivery properly, and keep your arm healthier. 

Pivot picks exaggerate your hip-shoulder separation and help you feel tension in your core before throwing.

Skills: Velocity, Back Leg Drive, Delivery, Hip Shoulder Separation

Skills: Velocity, Arm Path, Back Leg Drive, Hip Shoulder Separation, Lead Leg Block, Command

Description:

Skills: Velocity, Arm Path, Hip Shoulder Separation, Lead Leg Block

Description:

Description:
If your legs move slowly down the mound, your upper body has to compensate and fly open early in order to accelerate your arm. 

Walk-in throws help you build momentum with your lower half and rhythm in your delivery.
Skills: Velocity, Command, Back Leg Drive, Delivery

Description:
Rotating your hips while keeping your upper body closed allows you to generate the most power, sequence your delivery properly, and keep your arm healthier. 

Pivot picks exaggerate your hip-shoulder separation and how you should feel tension in your core before throwing.
Skills: Velocity, Arm Path, Hip Shoulder Separation, Lead Leg Block

Description:

Skills: Velocity, Back Leg Drive, Hip Shoulder Separation

Description:
Moving from foot strike to follow-through, you use your core to rotate and release the ball. 

Medball slams build explosiveness in your core that will translate to more power on the mound.
Skills: Velocity, Back Leg Drive, Hip Shoulder Separation

Description:
If used properly, your glove arm is a massive tool to help you throw harder and more accurately. 

Use your glove to pull your throwing arm forward and accelerate into your release point.

Drill Name: Dry Rep Leg Lift to Plant
Description:
You need to be balanced and strong in your position at foot strike in order to get the most out of your lower half. 

When you plant your front foot, make sure you feel tension in your core. 

This should feel like a powerful position to throw from.

If your upper body opens up before your lower half, you lose out on all of the power in your legs and put more strain on your arm than necessary. 

Use your back leg to drive forward before rotating with your upper body.
Skills: Velocity, Back Leg Drive, Hip Shoulder Separation, Lead Leg Block

Drill Name: Dry Rep Split Stance Kick Stand
Description:
Staying linear with home plate and throwing against your front leg helps your motion stay consistent and efficient. 

Owning this final part of your motion will build your arm speed and extension toward home plate.

Description:

Description:

Description:

Description:
Power comes from your legs, and starting stacked on your back leg allows you to drive down the mound with the most force. 

These dry reps build the muscle memory you need to control your motion using your back leg.

Releasing the ball as close to home plate as you can reduces the time the hitter has to see and react to your pitches. 

During this drill, you're building muscle memory to release the ball out in front of your body and accelerate into your release point.

Drill Name: Dry Rep Landing Spot Hip Rotations
Description:

Improving your extension toward home while throwing against your front leg allows you to put more power behind the ball and gives the hitter less time to react to your pitches. 

This drill helps build that muscle memory into your throwing motion.
Skills: Velocity, Arm Path, Command, Hip Shoulder Separation

Description:
Loading your back hip allows you to generate power and is the first step to driving down the mound with your legs. 

The step-back drill builds the feel of getting into your back hip and the muscle memory of using your back leg to drive your throwing motion.

How you pitch out of the windup—start with your body facing your target, take a small step sideways with your front foot, plant your back foot, and then lift your leg to throw. 

Build a natural rhythm in this motion.

Start off taking your signs from the catcher, step up so that your front foot is right next to your back foot, and hold this position before throwing. 

Play around with what feels the most comfortable and athletic for you in this stance.

Practice good posture with your core strong and shoulders rolled back.

Description:
Come set in the stretch and as you lift your leg, try to act the exact same as if you're throwing home—only step at a 45-degree angle toward first base and throw. 

Practice this to match your body and hand movements up with when you actually pitch.

Come set in the stretch and as you lift your leg, try to act the exact same as if you're throwing home—only step at a 45-degree angle toward first base and throw. 

Practice this to match your delivery to home.

Description:
In a quick pickoff to first base, start in the stretch and take a small step in place with your right foot. 

Turn your right foot so that it faces you toward first base and makes your throw quicker and easier.

After you come set and lift your leg, turn your shoulders and step toward second base, shuffle, and throw. 

Practice this to be a smooth, comfortable motion that closely matches your actual leg lift when pitching.

Drill Name: Half Kneeling Load In Medball Throws

In your foot strike position, you want to feel tension in your core that you use to rotate your upper body into release point.

The feel of keeping your back knee over your foot helps build the muscle memory of driving with your hips rather than your knee.

Description:

Get on hands and knees, place one hand behind your head, and lift your elbow up toward the ceiling.

Kneel next to a wall, press one arm against it at shoulder height, and twist your chest away from the wall.

Description:
